title: Create a solution
description: In this document, you will learn how to setup a solution from scratch.

children.value: In this document, you will learn how to setup a solution from scratch.
Create a solution folder for your application. Name it in the

). Under
this folder create an empty solution.

props.code:
mkdir Inventiv.Sample; cd Inventiv.Sample
dotnet new sln

children.value:
mkdir Inventiv.Sample; cd Inventiv.Sample
dotnet new sln

as a component throughout
this document.

To create a service application, first create a new web project by typing below
commands;

props.code:
dotnet new web --output src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Service
dotnet sln add src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Service --solution-folder src

children.value:
dotnet new web --output src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Service
dotnet sln add src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Service --solution-folder src

props.code:
Inventiv.Sample
└── src
    └── Inventiv.Sample.App.Service
        ├── Properties
        │   └── launchSettings.json
        ├── appsettings.json
        ├── appsettings.Developement.json
        └── Program.cs

children.value:
Inventiv.Sample
└── src
    └── Inventiv.Sample.App.Service
        ├── Properties
        │   └── launchSettings.json
        ├── appsettings.json
        ├── appsettings.Developement.json
        └── Program.cs

props.code: dotnet add src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Service package Gazel.Configuration

children.value: To configure this project to use Gazel, modify
As you can see there are 5 configurations;
tells Gazel to use a local

. This file will be
located in default user documents folder.

tells Gazel the
service url base to itself to be able to make internal calls.
tells Gazel to use console appenders in info level
You need to configure your application port correctly. You can go to

Gazel scans bin directory to configure your classes automatically. To
understand which assembly is yours, Gazel uses assembly name of your app
project. If your host project is named

then it will
only scan assemblies with a name that starts with
Now create another web project and name it after

props.code:
dotnet new web --output src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest
dotnet sln add src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest --solution-folder src

children.value:
dotnet new web --output src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest
dotnet sln add src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest --solution-folder src
Now your solution explorer should look like this;

props.code:
Inventiv.Sample
    └── src
        ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest
        │   ├── Properties
        │   │   └── launchSettings.json
        │   ├── appsettings.json
        │   ├── appsettings.Developement.json
        │   └── Program.cs
        └── Inventiv.Sample.App.Service

children.value:
Inventiv.Sample
    └── src
        ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest
        │   ├── Properties
        │   │   └── launchSettings.json
        │   ├── appsettings.json
        │   ├── appsettings.Developement.json
        │   └── Program.cs
        └── Inventiv.Sample.App.Service

props.code: dotnet add src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest package Gazel.Configuration

children.value: To configure this project to use Gazel, modify
As you can see there are 3 main configurations.

tells Gazel
to use previously created service application as a backend service.

tells Gazel to use standard rest configuration
which uses AspNetCore.Mvc template.
tells Gazel to use console appenders in info level

Now you've set up your environment to start developing a new backend. To add a
new business module to your project, check out next section.
In this document, you will learn how to setup a solution from scratch.
Create a solution folder for your application. Name it in the

). Under
this folder create an empty solution.

props.code:
mkdir Inventiv.Sample; cd Inventiv.Sample
dotnet new sln

as a component throughout
this document.

To create a service application, first create a new web project by typing below
commands;

props.code:
Inventiv.Sample

        │   ├── appsettings.json

props.code: dotnet add src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest package Gazel.Configuration

children.value: To configure this project to use Gazel, modify
As you can see there are 3 main configurations.

tells Gazel
to use previously created service application as a backend service.

tells Gazel to use standard rest configuration
which uses AspNetCore.Mvc template.
tells Gazel to use console appenders in info level

Now you've set up your environment to start developing a new backend. To add a
new business module to your project, check out next section.

title: Add a module
description:
In this document you will learn to create a new business module to your
existing solution.

children.value:
In this document you will learn to create a new business module to your
existing solution.

A module is a project that contains the domain logic of a specficic subset of
your backend, so choose a name accordingly. Naming convention for module
projects is
Now create a class library project under

props.code:
dotnet new classlib --output src/Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo
dotnet sln add src/Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo --solution-folder src

children.value:
dotnet new classlib --output src/Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo
dotnet sln add src/Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo --solution-folder src
Check if your solution has new module under

props.code:
Inventiv.Sample
└── src
    ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest
    ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Service
    └── Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo
dotnet add src/Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo package Gazel

children.value: Finally you need to add your module project reference to

so that
it renders and exposes business services in your new module.

props.code: dotnet add src/Inventiv.Sample.App.Service reference src/Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo

children.value:
To test your business services you need to create a test project. Naming
convention for test projects is
Add a new class library project under
package and module reference to the new project;

props.code:
dotnet new nunit --output test/Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo
dotnet sln add test/Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo --solution-folder test
dotnet add test/Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo package Gazel.Configuration
dotnet add test/Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo reference src/Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo

children.value:
dotnet new nunit --output test/Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo
dotnet sln add test/Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo --solution-folder test
dotnet add test/Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo package Gazel.Configuration
dotnet add test/Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo reference src/Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo
Your directory structure should look like this;

props.code:
Inventiv.Sample
├── src
│   ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest
│   ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Service
│   └── Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo
└── test
    └── Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo
        └── Usings.cs

children.value:
Inventiv.Sample
├── src
│   ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest
│   ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Service
│   └── Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo
└── test
    └── Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo
        └── Usings.cs
If your test project does not have

, you can add it manually.
Then add
